NEWS.TITLE: Info & Events (June 19)
NEWS.TEXT:
Visitors to the Haenyeo Museum can watch performances of Jeju female sea divers every Thursday.
Title - Jeju Female Sea Divers
Date - Thursdays 4-5 PM through October 31
Venue - Haenyeo Museum
Info - haenyeo.go.kr
Details - Haenyeo songs and dances
Foreign residents of the island are getting together Saturday for a number of musical performances.
Title - 2013 Expats in Jeju Summer Festival
Date - June 22, 6-8:30 PM
Venue - Tapdong Seaside Amphitheatre
Info- headlinejeju@headlinejeju.co.kr
Details - Bands, flea market, etc.
Jeju Philharmonic Orchestra is performing this Thursday.
Title - Night of Beethoven
Date - June 20 at 7:30 PM
Venue - Jeju Culture and Art Center
Info - jejuculture.or.kr
Details - The Creatures of Prometheus
Art by () Choi Hyung-hyang is on display at Changjak Studio, which is near the Lee Jung-seop Museum.
Title - Fairyland of Tamna
Date - Through June 21
Venue - Changjak Studio
Info - jslee.seogwipo.go.kr
Details - Choi Hyung-hyang
Club Blue Hill is hosting its 2013 Summer Music Fest next week.
Title - 2013 Summer Music Fest
Date - June 28-29
Venue - Club Blue Hill
Info - cafe.daum.net/clubbluehill
Details - Tickets by reservation only

NEWS.TITLE: Rice armyworms spotted for first time this year
NEWS.TEXT:
Environment
Rice armyworms spotted for first time this year
Discovered in Suwon-ri, Hallim-eup
Rice armyworms have been discovered for the first time this year, so agricultural authorities are urging farmers to take extra care to prevent the pests from damaging their crops.
Representatives from Jeju Agricultural Research and Extension Services recently spotted them while doing monitoring work in () Suwon-ri, (Ѹ) Hallim-eup.
The discovery was 17 days later than last year.
The agency is beefing up monitoring efforts and spraying pesticides around the area where the discovery was made.
The adult moths usually fly to Jeju from China between May and August.
Ѹ ù 갭 ߰
ù 갭 ߰ߵ ؿ濡 ǰ 䱸ǰ ֽϴ.

̿ 籹 Ȱ ȭϴ ߻ ߽ ֽϴ.
갭 ų 5 8 ̿ ߱ ƿ ظ ִ ǥ Դϴ

NEWS.TITLE: KCTV [More Exports ]
NEWS.TEXT:
[Ŀ] The JPDC is now focusing on the China as an export market for Jeju Samdasoo and another brand of bottled water. In addition pumping up sales, the corporation also wants to boost the image of Jeju water. Dean Brown reports.
[Ʈ] Last year, the volume of Samdasoo brand bottled water exported abroad stood at 3,600 tons, accounting for a mere 0.6 % of the total sold.
This figure also translates as just 7% of the original 50,000 ton export target.
The main reason cited for this is a contractual issue with the former exporters.
As such, the JPDC signed a new deal with CJ O shopping, and plans to expand bottled water exports, with a strong focus on the Chinese market.
CJ O shopping will have exported 120,000 tons, or 500 billion won worth of the (ټ) Samdasoo and (Ѷ) Hallasu brands through 2017.
The strategy laid out thus far is to promote Samdasoo as a mid- to high-priced bottled water, whilst Hallasu will compete with premium bottled water brands such as Evian.
This is all based on the JPDC's analysis that the credibility of Korean brands, and awareness of Jeju are both fairly high in China.
The packaging will be the same as domestically distributed bottles.
< Interview : Yi Hae-seon >
This year, exports of Jeju Samdasoo have been starting to recover.
Since March, it has been on sale in large retail outlets and department stores in Taiwan.
In April, the JPDC also signed an export contract with an Indonesian company.
Based on these positive results, the new target is to expand exports to 14 countries in total, increasing export volumes to 15,000 tons per annum.
< Interview : Oh Jae-yoon >
The JPDC plans to undertake an advertising campaign involving international cruise liners visiting Jeju, and to be an official sponsor of the 2014 Incheon Asian Games.
Industry insiders have high hopes that Jeju Samdasoo will achieve recognition as a world-class brand of bottled water, by means of aggressive marketing and a range of export strategies.
Dean Brown KCTV.

NEWS.TITLE: Arirang [Bracing for Rains ]
NEWS.TEXT:
[Ŀ] Turning to Arirang now, the start of the earliest rainy season on record in Korea has farmers scrambling to protect their crops from the torrential rains. In order to ensure they survive the downpours, government agencies are taking action with a wide-range of measures. Here's Arirang's Paul Yi to explain.
[Ʈ] Farmers here in North Chungcheong Province are fiercely working to draw off the excess water from their rice paddy fields, following the sudden flood of rain earlier this week.
They're trying to dig new irrigation paths to prepare for the next wave of heavy showers and it's hard work.
Farms across the country are bracing for the early monsoon season, but it's not just the strong winds or downpours that they're worried about.
The pools of stagnant water act as breeding grounds for plant diseases and insects.
[Interview] Son Dong-ok / Farmer, North Chungcheong Province "Since the rainy season is coming up, we're tying string around the peppers because they might fall. We're also spraying the crops ahead of time as a precaution."
Vigilant orchard owners are also taking the news of the early rains seriously.
Farmers are weatherproofing unripened fruit to ensure they don't fall from the trees.
However, these emergency preparations are only half the answer when it comes to the survival of these precious crops.
Damaged fruit and leaves need to be removed, then the fields are washed with clean water and disinfected with pesticides in order to remove any parasites or pathogens.
[Interview] Yang Chun-seok / N. Chungcheong ARES "We aid farmers during breaks in the rain by spraying pesticides. And for livestock farmers, we're going to have to thoroughly disinfect barns and livestock after the rains in an effort to prevent an outbreak of animal diseases."
[Arirang News] Paul Yi Greenhouses are another important measure in crop protection to keep out excess moisture and pests during the monsoon season, which is expected to last until mid to late July.
Paul Yi, Arirang News

NEWS.TITLE: Arirang [Tough Competition ]
NEWS.TEXT:
[Ŀ] Turning back to Arirang now, youth unemployment is becoming more commonplace in South Korea, making the job market even more competitive. So what are college students doing to prepare? Here's Arirang's Yoo Li-an to tell us.
[Ʈ] The low youth employment rate in Korea is driving young job seekers to do what they can to better their chances of getting a job, by acquiring new certifications and improving their appearance.
When a local research institute set out to find what young people think is most important when it comes to finding a job,... they found that English competence topped the list,... followed by certifications, college ranking, personal connections, and lastly, appearance.
The institute surveyed twelve-hundred students in middle ranked colleges.
A separate study showed that seven out of 10 college students in Korea believe that they need to spend money to improve their chances of getting a job.
Among those that spent on interview preparations, half were found to be spending about a hundred to three-hundred dollars each month.
So what are they spending it on?
Most of them said their money goes toward acquiring certifications, followed by interview clothes and accessories,... tuition for language institutes and plastic surgery. But with the new government's drive to prioritize aptitude over credentials,... will there be a shift in perceptions of what is important when it comes to job prep?
[Arirang News] Yoo Li-an Perhaps not anytime soon... Another survey from last month showed that eight in 10 job seekers said what's on their resumes mattered a lot when they were searching for a job during the first half of the recruitment season.
Yoo Li-an, Arirang News.

NEWS.TITLE: Rewards for energy-efficient households
NEWS.TEXT:
Administration
Rewards for energy-efficient households
Province to distribute 170m in gift certificates and cash
Households will be rewarded for cutting their electrical use through participation in what's known as a "carbon point system."
Jeju City will distribute 170 million won in Jeju Gift Certificates and cash to over 11,000 homes which signed on to the system in the second half of last year and which have cut their energy use by more than five percent.
The city is urging more residents to join the campaign, as experts are projecting that there will be a power shortage this summer, just like there was last.
More than 34,000 households signed up in the second half of 2012. They cut over 2,800 tons of greenhouse gas emissions and saved 6,730 kilowatts of energy.

NEWS.TITLE: Transportation allowance for students of rural high schools
NEWS.TEXT:
Administration
Transportation allowance for students of rural high schools
Province plans on giving 2,400 students \300,000 annually
The provincial government plans to give transportation allowances to the children of farmers who go to high schools in () eup and () myeon administrative districts.
The province recently announced an ordinance to that effect, and it is now accepting public opinion on the plan. The ordinance will take effect in September.
The children will have to have lived on the island for more than three months to receive the grants to help defray the costs of getting to and from school.
Officials estimate that some 2,400 students will qualify for the support, and that each will get 300,000 won annually.

NEWS.TITLE: Six reports of school violence daily
NEWS.TEXT:
Society
Six reports of school violence daily
Jeju 117 hotline fields 2,000+ calls in first year
Local authorities receive an average of six school violence reports daily.
The provincial police agency says the Jeju 1-1-7 school violence hotline has fielded 2,222 calls in the year since it opened.
That number is significant if you consider that the national school violence center only received 63 calls throughout all of last year.
634, or 46 percent, of the calls to the local center were to report physical violence, 342 were complaints of being insulted, and 133 involved some form of threat.
б Ű, Ϸ 6
Ϸ 6 б Ű Ǵ Ÿϴ.

NEWS.TITLE: Tropical Storm Leepi unlikely to affect Jeju
NEWS.TEXT:
Weather
Tropical Storm Leepi unlikely to affect Jeju
Forecasters say it will blow past Japan this weekend
Meteorologists say the fourth major storm of the season will pass the southern coast of Japan this weekend as it moves north, and is therefore unlikely to affect local weather conditions.
According to the Jeju Regional Meteorological Administration, Leepi is a weak, mid-sized tropical storm. It will blow through waters to the southeast of Tokyo between Friday and Saturday.
Forecasters say the only real evidence of the storm that will make it to Jeju will be abnormally high tides in the south of the island, so they are urging boat owners to take extra care of their vessels.

NEWS.TITLE: 119 to be emergency medical info hotline
NEWS.TEXT:
Society
119 to be emergency medical info hotline
1339 will be phased out; change goes into effect Saturday
In order to contact the emergency medical information center, callers must now dial 1-3-3-9, but that will soon change.
The Jeju Fire & Disaster Management Bureau says that beginning Saturday, callers will simply dial 1-1-9.
Staff at both hotlines have been offering the same medical advice since last June, and now the four-digit number will be phased out.
Officials say the change will simplify the process for the public, because now people need only remember one number for emergency medical advice and to request emergency medical services.
